3.1 Scattering and fluctuations

万物并作，吾以观复: 揭示临界乳光的物理和数学

In addition to bulk thermodynamic experiments, scattering measurements can be used to probe microscopic fluctuations at length scales of the order of the probe wavelength λ\lambdaλ. In a typical set up, a beam of wavevector ki\mathbf{k}_{i}ki​ is incident（入射） upon the sample and the scattered intensity is measured at wavevector ks=\mathbf{k}_{s}=ks​= ki+q\mathbf{k}_{i}+\mathbf{q}ki​+q. For elastic scattering, ∣ki∣=∣ks∣≡k\left|\mathbf{k}_{i}\right|=\left|\mathbf{k}_{s}\right| \equiv k∣ki​∣=∣ks​∣≡k, and q≡∣q∣=2ksin⁡θq \equiv|\mathbf{q}|=2 k \sin \thetaq≡∣q∣=2ksinθ, where θ\thetaθ is the angle between incident and scattered beams. 此处有误，这个角度并不是入射束和反射束的夹角。而是应该如图所示：

Standard treatments of scattering start with the Fermi golden rule, and usually lead to a scattering amplitude of the form

A(q)∝⟨ks⊗f∣U∣ki⊗i⟩∝σ(q)∫ddxeiq⋅xρ(x)\begin{equation*} A(\mathbf{q}) \propto\left\langle\mathbf{k}_{s} \otimes f\right| \mathcal{U}\left|\mathbf{k}_{i} \otimes i\right\rangle \propto \sigma(\mathbf{q}) \int \mathrm{d}^{d} \mathbf{x} \mathrm{e}^{\mathrm{i} \boldsymbol{q} \cdot \mathbf{x}} \rho(\mathbf{x}) \tag{3.1} \end{equation*}A(q)∝⟨ks​⊗f∣U∣ki​⊗i⟩∝σ(q)∫ddxeiq⋅xρ(x)​(3.1)​

In the above expression, ∣i⟩|i\rangle∣i⟩ and ∣f⟩|f\rangle∣f⟩ refer to the initial and final states of the sample, and U\mathcal{U}U is the scattering potential that can be decomposed as a sum due to the various scattering elements in the sample. The amplitude has a local form factor σ(q)\sigma(\mathbf{q})σ(q) describing the scattering from an individual element. For our purposes, the more interesting global information is contained in $\rho(\mathbf{q})$, the Fourier transform of the global density of scatterers $\rho(\mathbf{x})$. The appropriate scattering density depends on the nature of the probe. Light scattering senses the actual atomic density, electron scattering measures the charge density, while neutron scattering is usually used to probe the magnetization density. Most such probes actually do not respond to a snapshot of the system, but look at time averaged configurations. Thus the observed scattering intensity is

S(q)∝⟨∣A(q)∣2⟩∝⟨∣ρ(q)∣2⟩.\begin{equation*} \left.\left.\left.S(\mathbf{q}) \propto\langle | A(\mathbf{q})\right|^{2}\right\rangle\left.\propto\langle | \rho(\mathbf{q})\right|^{2}\right\rangle . \tag{3.2} \end{equation*}S(q)∝⟨∣A(q)∣2⟩∝⟨∣ρ(q)∣2⟩.​(3.2)​

Here ⟨∙⟩\langle\bullet\rangle⟨∙⟩ indicates the thermal average of ∙\bullet∙, which can be used in place of the time average in most cases due to ergodicity.

Equation (3.2) indicates that a uniform density only leads to forward scattering (q=0)(\mathbf{q}=\mathbf{0})(q=0), while the long-wavelength fluctuations can be studied by working at small angles or with small kkk. If scattering is caused by the magnetization density, we can use the Landau-Ginzburg Hamiltonian to compute its intensity. The probability of a particular configuration is given by

P[m⃗(x)]∝exp⁡{−∫ddx[K2(∇m)2+t2m2+um4]}.\begin{equation*} \mathcal{P}[\vec{m}(\mathbf{x})] \propto \exp \left\{-\int \mathrm{d}^{d} \mathbf{x}\left[\frac{K}{2}(\nabla m)^{2}+\frac{t}{2} m^{2}+u m^{4}\right]\right\} . \tag{3.3} \end{equation*}P[m(x)]∝exp{−∫ddx[2K​(∇m)2+2t​m2+um4]}.​(3.3)​

Landau-Ginzburg 哈密顿量的重要之处在于，它去掉了Higgs 势能的玄学味道。从对称性（旋转和平移），以及稳定性就可以确定最重要的 t2m2+um4{t\over 2 }m^2 + um^42t​m2+um4 形式，要使得在 t<0t<0t<0 的时候能够有稳定解，必须有 m4m^4m4 项！而 ttt 则是序参量（t=T−Tct=T-T_ct=T−Tc​）！

As discussed earlier, the most probable configuration is uniform, with m⃗(x)=\vec{m}(\mathbf{x})=m(x)= mˉe^1\bar{m} \widehat{e}_{1}mˉe1​, where e^1\widehat{e}_{1}e1​ is a unit vector ( mˉ\bar{m}mˉ is zero for t>0t>0t>0, and equal to −t/4u\sqrt{-t / 4 u}−t/4u​ for t<0t<0t<0 ). We can examine small fluctuations around such a configuration by setting

m⃗(x)=[mˉ+ϕℓ(x)]e^1+∑α=2nϕt,α(x)e^α\begin{equation*} \vec{m}(\mathbf{x})=\left[\bar{m}+\phi_{\ell}(\mathbf{x})\right] \widehat{e}_{1}+\sum_{\alpha=2}^{n} \phi_{t, \alpha}(\mathbf{x}) \widehat{e}_{\alpha} \tag{3.4} \end{equation*}m(x)=[mˉ+ϕℓ​(x)]e1​+α=2∑n​ϕt,α​(x)eα​​(3.4)​

这样的展开，和 Clebsch 参数化非常类似。

where ϕℓ\phi_{\ell}ϕℓ​ and ϕt\phi_{t}ϕt​ refer to longitudinal and transverse fluctuations, respectively. The latter can take place along any of the n−1n-1n−1 directions perpendicular to the average magnetization.

下面的分析非常物理，需要细细体会。

第一步：涨落分析

After the substitution of Eq. (3.4), the terms appearing in the Landau-Ginzburg Hamiltonian can be expanded to second order as

(∇m)2=(∇ϕℓ)2+(∇ϕt)2m2=mˉ2+2mˉϕℓ+ϕℓ2+ϕt2m4=mˉ4+4mˉ3ϕℓ+6mˉ2ϕℓ2+2mˉ2ϕt2+O(ϕℓ3,ϕt3)\begin{aligned} (\nabla m)^{2} & =\left(\nabla \phi_{\ell}\right)^{2}+\left(\nabla \phi_{t}\right)^{2} \\ m^{2} & =\bar{m}^{2}+2 \bar{m} \phi_{\ell}+\phi_{\ell}^{2}+\phi_{t}^{2} \\ m^{4} & =\bar{m}^{4}+4 \bar{m}^{3} \phi_{\ell}+6 \bar{m}^{2} \phi_{\ell}^{2}+2 \bar{m}^{2} \phi_{t}^{2}+\mathcal{O}\left(\phi_{\ell}^{3}, \phi_{t}^{3}\right) \end{aligned}(∇m)2m2m4​=(∇ϕℓ​)2+(∇ϕt​)2=mˉ2+2mˉϕℓ​+ϕℓ2​+ϕt2​=mˉ4+4mˉ3ϕℓ​+6mˉ2ϕℓ2​+2mˉ2ϕt2​+O(ϕℓ3​,ϕt3​)​

resulting in a quadratic energy cost

第二步：涨落自由能

βH≡−ln⁡P=V(t2mˉ2+umˉ4)+∫ddx[K2(∇ϕℓ)2+t+12umˉ22ϕℓ2]+∫ddx[K2(∇ϕt)2+t+4umˉ22ϕt2]+O(ϕℓ3,ϕt3).\begin{gather*} \beta \mathcal{H} \equiv-\ln \mathcal{P}=V\left(\frac{t}{2} \bar{m}^{2}+u \bar{m}^{4}\right)+\int \mathrm{d}^{d} \mathbf{x}\left[\frac{K}{2}\left(\nabla \phi_{\ell}\right)^{2}+\frac{t+12 u \bar{m}^{2}}{2} \phi_{\ell}^{2}\right] \tag{3.5}\\ +\int \mathrm{d}^{d} \mathbf{x}\left[\frac{K}{2}\left(\nabla \phi_{t}\right)^{2}+\frac{t+4 u \bar{m}^{2}}{2} \phi_{t}^{2}\right]+\mathcal{O}\left(\phi_{\ell}^{3}, \phi_{t}^{3}\right) . \end{gather*}βH≡−lnP=V(2t​mˉ2+umˉ4)+∫ddx[2K​(∇ϕℓ​)2+2t+12umˉ2​ϕℓ2​]+∫ddx[2K​(∇ϕt​)2+2t+4umˉ2​ϕt2​]+O(ϕℓ3​,ϕt3​).​(3.5)​

第三步：横向和纵向的均匀涨落。

这里用到了动量和尺度的分析

∂x↔1/ξ\partial_x \leftrightarrow 1/\xi∂x​↔1/ξ

这对于下面的刚度常数的分析至关重要。

For uniform distortions, the longitudinal and transverse restoring potentials have "stiffness（刚度） constants" given by

Kξℓ2≡t+12umˉ2=∂2Ψ(m)∂ϕℓ2∣mˉ={t for t>0−2t for t<0(3.6)\frac{K}{\xi_{\ell}^{2}} \equiv t+12 u \bar{m}^{2}=\left.\frac{\partial^{2} \Psi(m)}{\partial \phi_{\ell}^{2}}\right|_{\bar{m}}= \begin{cases}t & \text { for } t>0 \tag{3.6}\\ -2 t & \text { for } t<0\end{cases}ξℓ2​K​≡t+12umˉ2=∂ϕℓ2​∂2Ψ(m)​​mˉ​={t−2t​ for t>0 for t<0​(3.6)

and

Kξˉt2≡t+4umˉ2=∂2Ψ(m)∂ϕt2∣mˉ={t for t>00 for t<0(3.7)\frac{K}{\bar{\xi}_{t}^{2}} \equiv t+4 u \bar{m}^{2}=\left.\frac{\partial^{2} \Psi(m)}{\partial \phi_{t}^{2}}\right|_{\bar{m}}= \begin{cases}t & \text { for } t>0 \tag{3.7}\\ 0 & \text { for } t<0\end{cases}ξˉ​t2​K​≡t+4umˉ2=∂ϕt2​∂2Ψ(m)​​mˉ​={t0​ for t>0 for t<0​(3.7)

(The physical significance of the length scales ξℓ\xi_{\ell}ξℓ​ and ξt\xi_{t}ξt​ will soon become apparent.) Note that there is no distinction between longitudinal and transverse components for the paramagnet (t>0)(t>0)(t>0). For the ordered magnet in t<0t<0t<0, there is no restoring force for the transverse fluctuations which correspond to the Goldstone modes discussed in the previous section.

第四步：傅里叶分析。这么做的目的是推导出关联函数！从而可以分析纵向和横向的长波均匀激发模式在动量空间中的关联函数的形式。

Following the change of variables to the Fourier modes, ϕ(x)=\phi(\mathbf{x})=ϕ(x)= ∑qϕqeiq⋅x/V\sum_{q} \phi_{\mathbf{q}} \mathrm{e}^{\mathrm{iq} \cdot \mathrm{x}} / \sqrt{V}∑q​ϕq​eiq⋅x/V​, the probability of a particular fluctuation configuration is given by

P[{ϕℓ,q;ϕt,q}]∝∏qexp⁡{−K2(q2+ξℓ−2)∣ϕℓ,q∣2}⋅exp⁡{−K2(q2+ξt−2)∣ϕt,q∣2}(3.8)\mathcal{P}\left[\left\{\phi_{\ell, \mathbf{q}} ; \phi_{t, \mathbf{q}}\right\}\right] \propto \prod_{\mathbf{q}} \exp \left\{-\frac{K}{2}\left(q^{2}+\xi_{\ell}^{-2}\right)\left|\phi_{\ell, \mathbf{q}}\right|^{2}\right\} \cdot \exp \left\{-\frac{K}{2}\left(q^{2}+\xi_{t}^{-2}\right)\left|\phi_{t, \mathbf{q}}\right|^{2}\right\} \tag{3.8}P[{ϕℓ,q​;ϕt,q​}]∝q∏​exp{−2K​(q2+ξℓ−2​)∣ϕℓ,q​∣2}⋅exp{−2K​(q2+ξt−2​)∣ϕt,q​∣2}(3.8)

Clearly each mode behaves as a Gaussian random variable of zero mean, and the two-point correlation functions are

⟨ϕα,qϕβ,q′⟩=δα,β′δq,−q′K(q2+ξα−2),\begin{equation*} \left\langle\phi_{\alpha, \mathbf{q}} \phi_{\beta, \mathbf{q}^{\prime}}\right\rangle=\frac{\delta_{\alpha, \beta^{\prime}} \delta_{\mathbf{q},-\mathbf{q}^{\prime}}}{K\left(q^{2}+\xi_{\alpha}^{-2}\right)}, \tag{3.9} \end{equation*}⟨ϕα,q​ϕβ,q′​⟩=K(q2+ξα−2​)δα,β′​δq,−q′​​,​(3.9)​

where the indices refer to the longitudinal, or any of the transverse components. By using a spin polarized source of neutrons, the relative orientations can be adjusted to probe either the longitudinal or the transverse correlations. The Lorentzian form, $S(\mathbf{q}) \propto 1 /\left(q^{2}+\xi^{-2}\right)$, usually provides an excellent fit to scattering line shapes away from the critical point. Equation (3.9) indicates that in the ordered phase, longitudinal scattering still gives a Lorentzian form (on top of a delta function at q=0\mathbf{q}=\mathbf{0}q=0 due to the spontaneous magnetization), while transverse scattering always grows as 1/q21 / q^{2}1/q2. The same power law decay is also predicted to hold at the critical point, t=0t=0t=0. Actual experimental fits yield a power law of the form

S(q,T=Tc)∝1q2−η,\begin{equation*} S\left(\mathbf{q}, T=T_{c}\right) \propto \frac{1}{q^{2-\eta}}, \tag{3.10} \end{equation*}S(q,T=Tc​)∝q2−η1​,​(3.10)​

with a small positive value of $\eta$.

注意，这里的 η\etaη 实际上证明在 T→TcT\rightarrow T_cT→Tc​ 时， q→q1−η2q\rightarrow q^{1-{\eta\over 2}}q→q1−2η​, 这说明在临界点处，临界特征动量 qcq_cqc​ 附近的动量会更难偏离临界点。这说明在临界点附近，动量发生凝聚的可能性更大。

Fig. 3.1 The intensity of scattering by magnetic fluctuations for t>0t>0t>0 (left), and t<0t<0t<0 (right). The dashed line on the right indicates the transverse scattering intensity.

==结论：纵向长波激发不会有很大的改变，仍然是一个洛伦兹形式。但横向长波激发在临界点处偏离洛伦兹形式。相当于横向长波的关联长度 ξt\xi_tξt​ 在 t<0t<0t<0 (即临界温度以下（记住t=T−Tc<0t = T- T_c <0t=T−Tc​<0）) 趋于无穷大！==

3.2 Correlation functions and susceptibilities

主要是要计算体磁化率

We can also examine the extent of fluctuations in real space. The averages ⟨ϕα(x)⟩=⟨mα(x)−mˉα⟩\left\langle\phi_{\alpha}(\mathbf{x})\right\rangle=\left\langle m_{\alpha}(\mathbf{x})-\bar{m}_{\alpha}\right\rangle⟨ϕα​(x)⟩=⟨mα​(x)−mˉα​⟩, are clearly zero, and the connected correlation function is

Gα,βc(x,x′)≡⟨(mα(x)−mˉα)(mβ(x′)−mˉβ)⟩=⟨ϕα(x)ϕβ(x′)⟩=1V∑q,q′eiq⋅x+iq′⋅x′⟨ϕα,qϕβ,q′⟩.\begin{align*} G_{\alpha, \beta}^{c}\left(\mathbf{x}, \mathbf{x}^{\prime}\right) & \equiv\left\langle\left(m_{\alpha}(\mathbf{x})-\bar{m}_{\alpha}\right)\left(m_{\beta}\left(\mathbf{x}^{\prime}\right)-\bar{m}_{\beta}\right)\right\rangle \\ & =\left\langle\phi_{\alpha}(\mathbf{x}) \phi_{\beta}\left(\mathbf{x}^{\prime}\right)\right\rangle=\frac{1}{V} \sum_{\mathbf{q}, \mathbf{q}^{\prime}} \mathrm{e}^{\mathrm{i} \mathbf{q} \cdot \mathbf{x}+\mathrm{i} \mathbf{q}^{\prime} \cdot \mathbf{x}^{\prime}}\left\langle\phi_{\alpha, \mathbf{q}} \phi_{\beta, \mathbf{q}^{\prime}}\right\rangle . \tag{3.11} \end{align*}Gα,βc​(x,x′)​≡⟨(mα​(x)−mˉα​)(mβ​(x′)−mˉβ​)⟩=⟨ϕα​(x)ϕβ​(x′)⟩=V1​q,q′∑​eiq⋅x+iq′⋅x′⟨ϕα,q​ϕβ,q′​⟩.​(3.11)​

Using Eq. (3.9), we obtain

Gα,βc(x,x′)=δα,βV∑qeiq⋅(x−x′)K(q2+ξ˙α−2)≡−δα,βKId(x−x′,ξα),\begin{equation*} G_{\alpha, \beta}^{c}\left(\mathbf{x}, \mathbf{x}^{\prime}\right)=\frac{\delta_{\alpha, \beta}}{V} \sum_{\mathbf{q}} \frac{\mathrm{e}^{\mathrm{i} \mathbf{q} \cdot\left(\mathbf{x}-\mathbf{x}^{\prime}\right)}}{K\left(q^{2}+\dot{\xi}_{\alpha}^{-2}\right)} \equiv-\frac{\delta_{\alpha, \beta}}{K} I_{d}\left(\mathbf{x}-\mathbf{x}^{\prime}, \xi_{\alpha}\right), \tag{3.12} \end{equation*}Gα,βc​(x,x′)=Vδα,β​​q∑​K(q2+ξ˙​α−2​)eiq⋅(x−x′)​≡−Kδα,β​​Id​(x−x′,ξα​),​(3.12)​

where in the continuum limit,

Id(x,ξ)=−∫ddq(2π)deiq⋅xq2+ξ−2\begin{equation*} I_{d}(\mathbf{x}, \xi)=-\int \frac{\mathrm{d}^{d} \mathbf{q}}{(2 \pi)^{d}} \frac{\mathrm{e}^{\mathrm{i} \mathbf{q} \cdot \mathbf{x}}}{q^{2}+\xi^{-2}} \tag{3.13} \end{equation*}Id​(x,ξ)=−∫(2π)dddq​q2+ξ−2eiq⋅x​​(3.13)​

Alternatively, IdI_{d}Id​ is the solution to the following differential equation

∇2Id(x)=∫ddq(2π)dq2eiq⋅xq2+ξ−2=∫ddq(2π)d[1−ξ−2q2+ξ−2]eiq⋅x=δd(x)+Id(x)ξ2.\begin{equation*} \nabla^{2} I_{d}(x)=\int \frac{\mathrm{d}^{d} \mathbf{q}}{(2 \pi)^{d}} \frac{q^{2} \mathrm{e}^{\mathrm{i} \mathbf{q} \cdot \mathbf{x}}}{q^{2}+\xi^{-2}}=\int \frac{\mathrm{d}^{d} \mathbf{q}}{(2 \pi)^{d}}\left[1-\frac{\xi^{-2}}{q^{2}+\xi^{-2}}\right] \mathrm{e}^{\mathrm{i} \boldsymbol{q} \cdot \mathbf{x}}=\delta^{d}(\mathbf{x})+\frac{I_{d}(\mathbf{x})}{\xi^{2}} . \tag{3.14} \end{equation*}∇2Id​(x)=∫(2π)dddq​q2+ξ−2q2eiq⋅x​=∫(2π)dddq​[1−q2+ξ−2ξ−2​]eiq⋅x=δd(x)+ξ2Id​(x)​.​(3.14)​

The solution is spherically symmetric（注意，球坐标系里的拉普拉斯算子：

∇2f=1rd−1ddr(rd−1dfdr)\nabla^2 f = \frac{1}{r^{d-1}} \frac{d}{dr} \left( r^{d-1} \frac{df}{dr} \right)∇2f=rd−11​drd​(rd−1drdf​)

）, satisfying

d2Id dx2+d−1x dId dx=Idξ2+δd(x)\begin{equation*} \frac{\mathrm{d}^{2} I_{d}}{\mathrm{~d} x^{2}}+\frac{d-1}{x} \frac{\mathrm{~d} I_{d}}{\mathrm{~d} x}=\frac{I_{d}}{\xi^{2}}+\delta^{d}(\mathbf{x}) \tag{3.15} \end{equation*} dx2d2Id​​+xd−1​ dx dId​​=ξ2Id​​+δd(x)​(3.15)​

We can try out a solution that decays exponentially at large distances as（试探解，实际上这是因为对临界现象的势能关于距离的指数形式）

Id(x)∝exp⁡(−x/ξ)xp\begin{equation*} I_{d}(x) \propto \frac{\exp (-x / \xi)}{x^{p}} \tag{3.16} \end{equation*}Id​(x)∝xpexp(−x/ξ)​​(3.16)​

(We have anticipated the presence of a subleading power law.) The derivatives of IdI_{d}Id​ are given by

dId dx=−(px+1ξ)Id d2Id dx2=(p(p+1)x2+2pxξ+1ξ2)Id\begin{align*} \frac{\mathrm{d} I_{d}}{\mathrm{~d} x} & =-\left(\frac{p}{x}+\frac{1}{\xi}\right) I_{d} \\ \frac{\mathrm{~d}^{2} I_{d}}{\mathrm{~d} x^{2}} & =\left(\frac{p(p+1)}{x^{2}}+\frac{2 p}{x \xi}+\frac{1}{\xi^{2}}\right) I_{d} \tag{3.17} \end{align*} dxdId​​ dx2 d2Id​​​=−(xp​+ξ1​)Id​=(x2p(p+1)​+xξ2p​+ξ21​)Id​​(3.17)​

For x≠0x \neq 0x=0, the requirement that Eq. (3.16) satisfies Eq. (3.15) gives

p(p+1)x2+2pxξ+1ξ2−p(d−1)x2−(d−1)xξ=1ξ2\begin{equation*} \frac{p(p+1)}{x^{2}}+\frac{2 p}{x \xi}+\frac{1}{\xi^{2}}-\frac{p(d-1)}{x^{2}}-\frac{(d-1)}{x \xi}=\frac{1}{\xi^{2}} \tag{3.18} \end{equation*}x2p(p+1)​+xξ2p​+ξ21​−x2p(d−1)​−xξ(d−1)​=ξ21​​(3.18)​

The choice of ξ\xiξ as the decay length ensures that the constant terms in the above equation cancel. The exponent ppp is determined by requiring the next largest terms to cancel. For x≪ξx \ll \xix≪ξ, the 1/x21 / x^{2}1/x2 terms are the next most important; we must set p(p+1)=p(d−1)p(p+1)=p(d-1)p(p+1)=p(d−1), and p=d−2p=d-2p=d−2. This is the familiar exponent for Coulomb interactions, and indeed at this length scale the correlations don't feel the presence of ξ\xiξ. As demonstrated in the next section, the properly normalized result in this limit is

Id(x)≃Cd(x)=x2−d(2−d)Sd(x≪ξ)\begin{equation*} I_{d}(x) \simeq C_{d}(x)=\frac{x^{2-d}}{(2-d) S_{d}} \quad(x \ll \xi) \tag{3.19} \end{equation*}Id​(x)≃Cd​(x)=(2−d)Sd​x2−d​(x≪ξ)​(3.19)​

x≪ξx\ll \xix≪ξ ， 说明 exp⁡(−x/ξ)→1\exp(-x/\xi)\rightarrow1exp(−x/ξ)→1.

(Note that a constant term can always be added to the solution to satisfy the limits appropriate to the correlation function under study.) At large distances x≫ξx \gg \xix≫ξ, the 1/(xξ)1 /(x \xi)1/(xξ) term dominates Eq. (3.18), and ==its vanishing implies p=p=p= (d−1)/2(d-1) / 2(d−1)/2.== Matching to Eq. (3.19) at x≈ξx \approx \xix≈ξ yields

Id(x)≃ξ(3−d)/2(2−d)Sdx(d−1)/2exp⁡(−x/ξ)(x≫ξ)\begin{equation*} I_{d}(x) \simeq \frac{\xi^{(3-d) / 2}}{(2-d) S_{d} x^{(d-1) / 2}} \exp (-x / \xi) \quad(x \gg \xi) \tag{3.20} \end{equation*}Id​(x)≃(2−d)Sd​x(d−1)/2ξ(3−d)/2​exp(−x/ξ)(x≫ξ)​(3.20)​

From Eq. (3.12), we observe that transverse and longitudinal correlations behave differently. Close to the critical point, the longitudinal correlation length (Eq. 3.6) behaves as

ξℓ={t−1/2/K for t>0(−2t)−1/2/K for t<0(3.21)\xi_{\ell}= \begin{cases}t^{-1 / 2} / \sqrt{K} & \text { for } \mathrm{t}>0 \tag{3.21}\\ (-2 t)^{-1 / 2} / \sqrt{K} & \text { for } \mathrm{t}<0\end{cases}ξℓ​={t−1/2/K​(−2t)−1/2/K​​ for t>0 for t<0​(3.21)

The singularities can be described by ξ±≃ξ0B±∣t∣−ν±\xi_{ \pm} \simeq \xi_{0} B_{ \pm}|t|^{-\nu_{ \pm}}ξ±​≃ξ0​B±​∣t∣−ν±​, where ν±=1/2\nu_{ \pm}=1 / 2ν±​=1/2 and B+/B−=2B_{+} / B_{-}=\sqrt{2}B+​/B−​=2​ are universal, while ξ0∝1/K\xi_{0} \propto 1 / \sqrt{K}ξ0​∝1/K​ is not(物质依赖). The transverse correlation length (Eq. 3.7) equals ξℓ\xi_{\ell}ξℓ​ for t>0t>0t>0, and is infinite for all t<0t<0t<0.

Equation (3.19) implies that right at TcT_{c}Tc​, correlations decay as 1/xd−21 / x^{d-2}1/xd−2. Actually, the decay exponent is usually indicated by 1/xd−2+η1 / x^{d-2+\eta}1/xd−2+η, where η\etaη is the same exponent introduced in Eq. (3.10).

Integrating the connected correlation functions results in bulk susceptibilities. （体磁化率=连通格林函数的积分）

For example, the divergence of the longitudinal susceptibility is also obtained from,

χℓ∝∫ddxGℓc(x)∝∫0ξℓddxxd−2∝ξℓ2≃A±t−1\begin{equation*} \chi_{\ell} \propto \int \mathrm{d}^{d} \mathbf{x} G_{\ell}^{c}(\mathbf{x}) \propto \int_{0}^{\xi_{\ell}} \frac{\mathrm{d}^{d} x}{x^{d-2}} \propto \xi_{\ell}^{2} \simeq A_{ \pm} t^{-1} \tag{3.22} \end{equation*}χℓ​∝∫ddxGℓc​(x)∝∫0ξℓ​​xd−2ddx​∝ξℓ2​≃A±​t−1​(3.22)​

The universal exponents and amplitude ratios are again recovered from the above equation. For T<TcT<T_{c}T<Tc​, there is no upper cut-off length for transverse correlations（$\xi_t$ 在临界温度之下是无穷大）, and the divergence of the transverse susceptibility can be related to the system size LLL, as

χt∝∫ ddxGtc(x)∝∫0L ddxxd−2∝L2\begin{equation*} \chi_{t} \propto \int \mathrm{~d}^{d} \mathbf{x} G_{t}^{c}(\mathbf{x}) \propto \int_{0}^{L} \frac{\mathrm{~d}^{d} x}{x^{d-2}} \propto L^{2} \tag{3.23} \end{equation*}χt​∝∫ ddxGtc​(x)∝∫0L​xd−2 ddx​∝L2​(3.23)​

3.3 Lower critical dimension

In chapter 2 we discussed how the breaking of a continuous symmetry is accompanied by the appearance of low energy excitations (Goldstone modes). These modes are easily excited by thermal fluctuations, and we may inquire about the effect of such fluctuations on the ordered phase. Let us first consider the case of a superfluid in the ordered phase, with a local order parameter (see Eq. 2.21) ψ(x)=∣ψ(x)∣eiθ(x)\psi\left(\mathbf{x}\right)=|\psi(\mathbf{x})| \mathrm{e}^{\mathrm{i} \theta(\mathbf{x})}ψ(x)=∣ψ(x)∣eiθ(x). Assuming that the amplitude of the order parameter is uniform (意味着∣ψ(x)∣=const.|\psi({\mathbf x})| = \text{const.}∣ψ(x)∣=const.), the probability of a particular configuration is given by

P[θ(x)]∝exp⁡[−Kˉ2∫ ddx(∇θ)2].\begin{equation*} \mathcal{P}[\theta(\mathbf{x})] \propto \exp \left[-\frac{\bar{K}}{2} \int \mathrm{~d}^{d} \mathbf{x}(\nabla \theta)^{2}\right] . \tag{3.24} \end{equation*}P[θ(x)]∝exp[−2Kˉ​∫ ddx(∇θ)2].​(3.24)​

Fig. 3.2 The decay of correlations as a function of separation, away from criticality.

Alternatively, in terms of the Fourier components,

P[θ(q)]∝exp⁡[−Kˉ2∑qq2∣θ(q)∣2]∝∏qp(θq).\begin{equation*} \mathcal{P}[\theta(\mathbf{q})] \propto \exp \left[-\frac{\bar{K}}{2} \sum_{\mathbf{q}} q^{2}|\theta(\mathbf{q})|^{2}\right] \propto \prod_{\mathbf{q}} p\left(\theta_{\mathbf{q}}\right) . \tag{3.25} \end{equation*}P[θ(q)]∝exp[−2Kˉ​q∑​q2∣θ(q)∣2]∝q∏​p(θq​).​(3.25)​

Each mode θq\theta_{\mathbf{q}}θq​ is an independent random variable with a Gaussian distribution of zero mean, and with 1{ }^{1}1

⟨θq′θq′⟩=δq,−q′Kˉq2\begin{equation*} \left\langle\theta_{\mathbf{q}^{\prime}} \theta_{\mathbf{q}^{\prime}}\right\rangle=\frac{\delta_{\mathbf{q},-\mathbf{q}^{\prime}}}{\bar{K} q^{2}} \tag{3.26} \end{equation*}⟨θq′​θq′​⟩=Kˉq2δq,−q′​​​(3.26)​

From Eq. (3.26) we can calculate the correlations in the phase θ(x)\theta(\mathbf{x})θ(x) in real space. Clearly ⟨θ(x)⟩=0\langle\theta(\mathbf{x})\rangle=0⟨θ(x)⟩=0 by symmetry, while

⟨θ(x)θ(x′)⟩=1V∑q,q′eiq⋅x+q′⋅x′⟨θqθq′⟩=1V∑qeiq⋅(x−x′)Kˉq2\begin{equation*} \left\langle\theta(\mathbf{x}) \theta\left(\mathbf{x}^{\prime}\right)\right\rangle=\frac{1}{V} \sum_{\mathbf{q}, \mathbf{q}^{\prime}} \mathrm{e}^{\mathrm{iq} \cdot \mathbf{x}+\mathbf{q}^{\prime} \cdot \mathbf{x}^{\prime}}\left\langle\theta_{\mathbf{q}} \theta_{\mathbf{q}^{\prime}}\right\rangle=\frac{1}{V} \sum_{\mathbf{q}} \frac{\mathrm{e}^{\mathrm{iq} \cdot\left(\mathbf{x}-\mathbf{x}^{\prime}\right)}}{\bar{K} q^{2}} \tag{3.27} \end{equation*}⟨θ(x)θ(x′)⟩=V1​q,q′∑​eiq⋅x+q′⋅x′⟨θq​θq′​⟩=V1​q∑​Kˉq2eiq⋅(x−x′)​​(3.27)​

In the continuum limit, the sum can be replaced by an integral (∑q↦\left(\sum_{\mathbf{q}} \mapsto\right.(∑q​↦ V∫ ddq/(2π)d)\left.V \int \mathrm{~d}^{d} \mathbf{q} /(2 \pi)^{d}\right)V∫ ddq/(2π)d), and

⟨θ(x)θ(x′)⟩=∫ddqq(2π)deiq⋅(x−x′)Kˉq2=−Cd(x−x′)Kˉ.\begin{equation*} \left\langle\theta(\mathbf{x}) \theta\left(\mathbf{x}^{\prime}\right)\right\rangle=\int \frac{\mathrm{d}^{d} \mathbf{q} \mathbf{q}}{(2 \pi)^{d}} \frac{\mathrm{e}^{\mathrm{i} \mathbf{q} \cdot\left(\mathbf{x}-\mathbf{x}^{\prime}\right)}}{\bar{K} q^{2}}=-\frac{C_{d}\left(\mathbf{x}-\mathbf{x}^{\prime}\right)}{\bar{K}} . \tag{3.28} \end{equation*}⟨θ(x)θ(x′)⟩=∫(2π)dddqq​Kˉq2eiq⋅(x−x′)​=−KˉCd​(x−x′)​.​(3.28)​

The function,

Cd(x)=−∫ddq(2π)deiq⋅xq2,\begin{equation*} C_{d}(\mathbf{x})=-\int \frac{\mathrm{d}^{d} \mathbf{q}}{(2 \pi)^{d}} \frac{\mathrm{e}^{\mathrm{i} \mathbf{q} \cdot \mathbf{x}}}{q^{2}}, \tag{3.29} \end{equation*}Cd​(x)=−∫(2π)dddq​q2eiq⋅x​,​(3.29)​

is the **Coulomb potential due to a unit charge at the origin in a $d$-dimensional space, since it is the solution to**

∇2Cd(x)=∫ddq(2π)dq2q2eiq⋅x=δd(x)\begin{equation*} \nabla^{2} C_{d}(\mathbf{x})=\int \frac{\mathrm{d}^{d} \mathbf{q}}{(2 \pi)^{d}} \frac{q^{2}}{q^{2}} e^{\mathrm{i} \mathbf{q} \cdot \mathbf{x}}=\delta^{d}(\mathbf{x}) \tag{3.30} \end{equation*}∇2Cd​(x)=∫(2π)dddq​q2q2​eiq⋅x=δd(x)​(3.30)​

We can easily find a solution by using Gauss' theorem,

∫ddx∇2Cd=∮dS⋅∇Cd.\int \mathrm{d}^{d} x \nabla^{2} C_{d}=\oint \mathrm{d} S \cdot \nabla C_{d} .∫ddx∇2Cd​=∮dS⋅∇Cd​.

1 Note that the Fourier transform of a real field θ(x)\theta(\mathbf{x})θ(x) is complex θq=θq,ℜ+iθq,ℑ\theta_{\mathbf{q}}=\theta_{\mathbf{q}, \Re}+\mathrm{i} \theta_{\mathbf{q}, \Im}θq​=θq,ℜ​+iθq,ℑ​. While the first product is over all q\mathbf{q}q, the second is restricted to half of the space. There are clearly no cross correlations for differing q\mathbf{q}q, and the Gaussian variances are

⟨θq,ℜ⟩=⟨θq,ℑ2⟩=12K(q),\left\langle\theta_{\mathbf{q}, \Re}\right\rangle=\left\langle\theta_{\mathbf{q}, \Im}^{2}\right\rangle=\frac{1}{2 K(q)},⟨θq,ℜ​⟩=⟨θq,ℑ2​⟩=2K(q)1​,

from which we can immediately construct

⟨θqθ∓q⟩=⟨θq,ℜ2⟩±⟨θq,ℑ2⟩=1±12K(q)\left\langle\theta_{\mathbf{q}} \theta_{\mp \mathbf{q}}\right\rangle=\left\langle\theta_{\mathbf{q}, \mathfrak{\Re}}^{2}\right\rangle \pm\left\langle\theta_{\mathbf{q}, \Im}^{2}\right\rangle=\frac{1 \pm 1}{2 K(q)}⟨θq​θ∓q​⟩=⟨θq,ℜ2​⟩±⟨θq,ℑ2​⟩=2K(q)1±1​

For a spherically symmetric solution, ∇Cd=(dCd/dx)x^\nabla C_{d}=\left(\mathrm{d} C_{d} / \mathrm{d} x\right) \widehat{x}∇Cd​=(dCd​/dx)x, and the above equation（公式(3.30)） simplifies to

∇2Cd(x)=δd(x)⇒1=Sdxd−1 dCd dx\begin{equation*} \nabla^2 C_d(\mathbf x) = \delta^d(\mathbf x)\Rightarrow1=S_{d} x^{d-1} \frac{\mathrm{~d} C_{d}}{\mathrm{~d} x} \tag{3.31} \end{equation*}∇2Cd​(x)=δd(x)⇒1=Sd​xd−1 dx dCd​​​(3.31)​

这里使用了高斯定理。

where

Sd=2πd/2(d/2−1)!\begin{equation*} S_{d}=\frac{2 \pi^{d / 2}}{(d / 2-1)!} \tag{3.32} \end{equation*}Sd​=(d/2−1)!2πd/2​​(3.32)​

is the total solid angle (area of unit sphere) in ddd dimensions. Hence

dCd dx=1Sdxd−1⟹Cd(x)=x2−d(2−d)Sd+c0\begin{equation*} \frac{\mathrm{d} C_{d}}{\mathrm{~d} x}=\frac{1}{S_{d} x^{d-1}} \quad \Longrightarrow \quad C_{d}(x)=\frac{x^{2-d}}{(2-d) S_{d}}+c_{0} \tag{3.33} \end{equation*} dxdCd​​=Sd​xd−11​⟹Cd​(x)=(2−d)Sd​x2−d​+c0​​(3.33)​

where c0c_{0}c0​ is a constant of integration. The long distance behavior of Cd(x)C_{d}(x)Cd​(x) changes dramatically at d=2d=2d=2, as

lim⁡x→∞Cd(x)={c0d>2x2−d(2−d)Sdd<2ln⁡(x)2πd=2(3.34)\lim _{x \rightarrow \infty} C_{d}(x)= \begin{cases}c_{0} & d>2 \tag{3.34}\\ \frac{x^{2-d}}{(2-d) S_{d}} & d<2 \\ \frac{\ln (x)}{2 \pi} & d=2\end{cases}x→∞lim​Cd​(x)=⎩⎨⎧​c0​(2−d)Sd​x2−d​2πln(x)​​d>2d<2d=2​(3.34)

The constant of integration can obtained by looking at

⟨[θ(x)−θ(x′)]2⟩=2⟨θ(x)2⟩−2⟨θ(x)θ(x′)⟩,\begin{equation*} \left\langle\left[\theta(\mathbf{x})-\theta\left(\mathbf{x}^{\prime}\right)\right]^{2}\right\rangle=2\left\langle\theta(\mathbf{x})^{2}\right\rangle-2\left\langle\theta(\mathbf{x}) \theta\left(\mathbf{x}^{\prime}\right)\right\rangle, \tag{3.35} \end{equation*}⟨[θ(x)−θ(x′)]2⟩=2⟨θ(x)2⟩−2⟨θ(x)θ(x′)⟩,​(3.35)​

which goes to zero as x→x′\mathbf{x} \rightarrow \mathbf{x}^{\prime}x→x′. Hence,

⟨[θ(x)−θ(x′)]2⟩=2(∣x−x′∣2−d−a2−d)Kˉ(2−d)Sd\begin{equation*} \left\langle\left[\theta(\mathbf{x})-\theta\left(\mathbf{x}^{\prime}\right)\right]^{2}\right\rangle=\frac{2\left(\left|\mathbf{x}-\mathbf{x}^{\prime}\right|^{2-d}-a^{2-d}\right)}{\bar{K}(2-d) S_{d}} \tag{3.36} \end{equation*}⟨[θ(x)−θ(x′)]2⟩=Kˉ(2−d)Sd​2(∣x−x′∣2−d−a2−d)​​(3.36)​

where aaa is of the order of the lattice spacing. For d>2d>2d>2, the phase fluctuations are finite, while they become asymptotically large for d≤2d \leq 2d≤2. Since the phase is bounded by $2 \pi$, this implies that longrange order in the phase is destroyed. This result becomes more apparent by examining the effect of phase fluctuations on the two-point correlation function

⟨ψ(x)ψ∗(0)⟩=ψˉ2⟨ei[θ(x)−θ(0)]⟩.\begin{equation*} \left\langle\psi(\mathbf{x}) \psi^{*}(\mathbf{0})\right\rangle=\bar{\psi}^{2}\left\langle\mathrm{e}^{\mathrm{i}[\theta(\mathbf{x})-\theta(\mathbf{0})]}\right\rangle . \tag{3.37} \end{equation*}⟨ψ(x)ψ∗(0)⟩=ψˉ​2⟨ei[θ(x)−θ(0)]⟩.​(3.37)​

(Since amplitude fluctuations are ignored, we are in fact looking at a transverse correlation function.) We shall prove later on that for any collection of Gaussian distributed variables,

⟨exp⁡(αθ)⟩=exp⁡(α22⟨θ2⟩)\langle\exp (\alpha \theta)\rangle=\exp \left(\frac{\alpha^{2}}{2}\left\langle\theta^{2}\right\rangle\right)⟨exp(αθ)⟩=exp(2α2​⟨θ2⟩)

Taking this result for granted, we obtain

⟨ψ(x)ψ∗(0)⟩=ψˉ2exp⁡[−12⟨[θ(x)−θ(0)]2⟩]=ψˉ2exp⁡[−x2−d−a2−dKˉ(2−d)Sd],\begin{equation*} \left\langle\psi(\mathbf{x}) \psi^{*}(0)\right\rangle=\bar{\psi}^{2} \exp \left[-\frac{1}{2}\left\langle[\theta(\mathbf{x})-\theta(\mathbf{0})]^{2}\right\rangle\right]=\bar{\psi}^{2} \exp \left[-\frac{x^{2-d}-a^{2-d}}{\bar{K}(2-d) S_{d}}\right], \tag{3.38} \end{equation*}⟨ψ(x)ψ∗(0)⟩=ψˉ​2exp[−21​⟨[θ(x)−θ(0)]2⟩]=ψˉ​2exp[−Kˉ(2−d)Sd​x2−d−a2−d​],​(3.38)​

and asymptotically

lim⁡x→∞⟨ψ(x)ψ∗(0)⟩={ψˉ2 for d>20 for d≤2(3.39)\lim _{x \rightarrow \infty}\left\langle\psi(\mathbf{x}) \psi^{*}(\mathbf{0})\right\rangle= \begin{cases}\bar{\psi}^{2} & \text { for } d>2 \tag{3.39}\\ 0 & \text { for } d \leq 2\end{cases}x→∞lim​⟨ψ(x)ψ∗(0)⟩={ψˉ​20​ for d>2 for d≤2​(3.39)

The saddle point approximation to the order parameter ψˉ\bar{\psi}ψˉ​ was obtained by ignoring fluctuations. The above result indicates that inclusion of phase fluctuations leads to a reduction of order in d>2d>2d>2, and its complete destruction in d≤2d \leq 2d≤2.

The above example typifies a more general result known as the Mermin-Wagner theorem. The theorem states that there is no spontaneous breaking of a continuous symmetry in systems with short-range interactions in dimensions d≤2d \leq 2d≤2. Some corollaries to this theorem are: (1) The borderline dimensionality of two, known as the lower critical dimension, has to be treated carefully. As we shall demonstrate later on in the course, there is in fact a phase transition for the two-dimensional superfluid, although there is no true long-range order. (2) There are no Goldstone modes when the broken symmetry is discrete (e.g. for n=1n=1n=1 ). In such cases, long-range order is possible down to the lower critical dimension of dℓ=1d_{\ell}=1dℓ​=1.

3.4 Comparison to experiments

The true test of the validity of the theoretical results comes from comparison to experiments. A rather rough table of critical exponents is provided below for a quick check:

Transition type Material α\alphaα β\betaβ γ\gammaγ ν\nuν
Ferromagnets (n=3)(n=3)(n=3) Fe,Ni\mathrm{Fe}, \mathrm{Ni}Fe,Ni -0.1 0.4 1.3
Superfluid (n=2)(n=2)(n=2) He4\mathrm{He}^{4}He4 0 0.3 1.3 0.7
Liquid-gas (n=1)(n=1)(n=1) CO2,Xe\mathrm{CO}_{2}, \mathrm{Xe}CO2​,Xe 0.1 0.3 1.2 0.7
Ferroelectrics TGS 0 1/21 / 21/2 1 1/21 / 21/2
and superconductors
Mean-field theory 0 1/21 / 21/2 1 1/21 / 21/2

The exponents are actually known to much better accuracy than indicated in this table. The final row (mean-field theory) refers to the results obtained from the saddle point approximation. They agree only with the experiments on ferroelectric and superconducting materials. The disagreement between the exponents for different values of nnn suggests that the mean-field results are too universal, and leave out some essential dependence on nnn (and ddd ). How do we account for these discrepancies? The starting point of the Landau-Ginzburg Hamiltonian is sufficiently general to be trustworthy. The difficulty is in the saddle point method used in the evaluation of its partition function, as will become apparent in the following sections.

3.5 Gaussian integrals

In the previous section the energy cost of fluctuations was calculated at quadratic order. These fluctuations also modify the saddle point free energy. Before calculating this modification, we take a short (but necessary) mathematical diversion on computing Gaussian integrals.

The simplest Gaussian integral involves one variable ϕ\phiϕ,

J1=∫−∞∞dϕe−K2ϕ2+hϕ=2πKeh22K.\begin{equation*} \mathcal{J}_{1}=\int_{-\infty}^{\infty} \mathrm{d} \phi \mathrm{e}^{-\frac{K}{2} \phi^{2}+h \phi}=\sqrt{\frac{2 \pi}{K}} \mathrm{e}^{\frac{h^{2}}{2 K} .} \tag{3.40} \end{equation*}J1​=∫−∞∞​dϕe−2K​ϕ2+hϕ=K2π​​e2Kh2​.​(3.40)​

By taking derivatives of the above expression with respect to hhh, integrals involving powers of ϕ\phiϕ are generated; e.g.

d dh:∫−∞∞dϕϕe−K2ϕ2+hϕ=2πKeh22K⋅hK d2 dh2:∫−∞∞dϕϕ2e−K2ϕ2+hϕ=2πKeh22K⋅[1K+h2K2]\begin{align*} \frac{\mathrm{d}}{\mathrm{~d} h}: \int_{-\infty}^{\infty} \mathrm{d} \phi \phi \mathrm{e}^{-\frac{K}{2} \phi^{2}+h \phi} & =\sqrt{\frac{2 \pi}{K}} \mathrm{e}^{\frac{h^{2}}{2 K}} \cdot \frac{h}{K} \\ \frac{\mathrm{~d}^{2}}{\mathrm{~d} h^{2}}: \int_{-\infty}^{\infty} \mathrm{d} \phi \phi^{2} \mathrm{e}^{-\frac{K}{2} \phi^{2}+h \phi} & =\sqrt{\frac{2 \pi}{K}} \mathrm{e}^{\frac{h^{2}}{2 K}} \cdot\left[\frac{1}{K}+\frac{h^{2}}{K^{2}}\right] \tag{3.41} \end{align*} dhd​:∫−∞∞​dϕϕe−2K​ϕ2+hϕ dh2 d2​:∫−∞∞​dϕϕ2e−2K​ϕ2+hϕ​=K2π​​e2Kh2​⋅Kh​=K2π​​e2Kh2​⋅[K1​+K2h2​]​(3.41)​

If the integrand represents the probability density of the random variable ϕ\phiϕ, the above integrals imply the moments ⟨ϕ⟩=h/K\langle\phi\rangle=h / K⟨ϕ⟩=h/K, and ⟨ϕ2⟩=h2/K2+1/K\left\langle\phi^{2}\right\rangle=h^{2} / K^{2}+1 / K⟨ϕ2⟩=h2/K2+1/K. The corresponding cumulants are ⟨ϕ⟩c=⟨ϕ⟩=h/K\langle\phi\rangle_{c}=\langle\phi\rangle=h / K⟨ϕ⟩c​=⟨ϕ⟩=h/K, and ⟨ϕ2⟩c=⟨ϕ2⟩−⟨ϕ⟩2=\left\langle\phi^{2}\right\rangle_{c}=\left\langle\phi^{2}\right\rangle-\langle\phi\rangle^{2}=⟨ϕ2⟩c​=⟨ϕ2⟩−⟨ϕ⟩2= 1/K1 / K1/K. In fact all higher order cumulants of the Gaussian distribution are zero since

⟨e−ikϕ⟩≡exp⁡[∑ℓ=1∞(−ik)ℓℓ!⟨ϕℓ⟩c]=exp⁡[−ikh−k22K]\begin{equation*} \left\langle\mathrm{e}^{-\mathrm{i} k \phi}\right\rangle \equiv \exp \left[\sum_{\ell=1}^{\infty} \frac{(-\mathrm{i} k)^{\ell}}{\ell!}\left\langle\phi^{\ell}\right\rangle_{c}\right]=\exp \left[-\mathrm{i} k h-\frac{k^{2}}{2 K}\right] \tag{3.42} \end{equation*}⟨e−ikϕ⟩≡exp[ℓ=1∑∞​ℓ!(−ik)ℓ​⟨ϕℓ⟩c​]=exp[−ikh−2Kk2​]​(3.42)​

这个等式涉及到统计力学中的特征函数和累积量（cumulants）的概念。我们可以通过特征函数的展开和累积量的性质来理解这个等式。

  1. 特征函数：对于一个随机变量 ϕ\phiϕ，其特征函数定义为：

    ⟨e−ikϕ⟩\left\langle e^{-\mathrm{i} k \phi} \right\rangle⟨e−ikϕ⟩

    这是 ϕ\phiϕ 的概率分布的傅里叶变换。

  2. 累积量展开：特征函数可以用累积量展开表示为：

    ⟨e−ikϕ⟩=exp⁡[∑ℓ=1∞(−ik)ℓℓ!⟨ϕℓ⟩c]\left\langle e^{-\mathrm{i} k \phi} \right\rangle = \exp \left[ \sum_{\ell=1}^{\infty} \frac{(-\mathrm{i} k)^{\ell}}{\ell!} \left\langle \phi^{\ell} \right\rangle_c \right]⟨e−ikϕ⟩=exp[ℓ=1∑∞​ℓ!(−ik)ℓ​⟨ϕℓ⟩c​]

    其中，⟨ϕℓ⟩c\left\langle \phi^{\ell} \right\rangle_c⟨ϕℓ⟩c​ 是 ϕ\phiϕ 的第 ℓ\ellℓ 阶累积量。

    这个展开是基于累积量生成函数的性质。累积量生成函数是一个非常有用的工具，用于描述随机变量的分布特性，特别是在处理正态分布时。

    累积量生成函数

    对于一个随机变量 ϕ\phiϕ，其累积量生成函数 K(t)K(t)K(t) 定义为：

    K(t)=log⁡⟨etϕ⟩K(t) = \log \left\langle e^{t \phi} \right\rangleK(t)=log⟨etϕ⟩

    累积量生成函数的性质是，它的导数在 t=0t=0t=0 处给出累积量：

    • 第一阶导数给出第一阶累积量（均值）：K′(0)=⟨ϕ⟩cK'(0) = \left\langle \phi \right\rangle_cK′(0)=⟨ϕ⟩c​
    • 第二阶导数给出第二阶累积量（方差）：K′′(0)=⟨ϕ2⟩cK''(0) = \left\langle \phi^2 \right\rangle_cK′′(0)=⟨ϕ2⟩c​
    • 高阶导数给出高阶累积量
    正态分布的特性

    对于正态分布，累积量生成函数的形式非常简单，因为正态分布的所有高阶累积量（ℓ≥3\ell \geq 3ℓ≥3）都为零。这意味着：

    K(t)=⟨ϕ⟩ct+12⟨ϕ2⟩ct2K(t) = \left\langle \phi \right\rangle_c t + \frac{1}{2} \left\langle \phi^2 \right\rangle_c t^2K(t)=⟨ϕ⟩c​t+21​⟨ϕ2⟩c​t2

    因此，特征函数可以写为：

    ⟨etϕ⟩=exp⁡(K(t))=exp⁡(⟨ϕ⟩ct+12⟨ϕ2⟩ct2)\left\langle e^{t \phi} \right\rangle = \exp \left( K(t) \right) = \exp \left( \left\langle \phi \right\rangle_c t + \frac{1}{2} \left\langle \phi^2 \right\rangle_c t^2 \right)⟨etϕ⟩=exp(K(t))=exp(⟨ϕ⟩c​t+21​⟨ϕ2⟩c​t2)

    对于正态分布，特征函数的展开只需要考虑到二阶累积量，因为高阶累积量为零。这个性质使得正态分布在统计分析中非常简洁和有用。

假设 ϕ\phiϕ 是一个正态分布的随机变量，其均值为 hhh，方差为 KKK。对于正态分布，累积量的性质如下：

  • 第一阶累积量：⟨ϕ⟩c=h\left\langle \phi \right\rangle_c = h⟨ϕ⟩c​=h
  • 第二阶累积量：⟨ϕ2⟩c=K\left\langle \phi^2 \right\rangle_c = K⟨ϕ2⟩c​=K
  • 高阶累积量：对于 ℓ≥3\ell \geq 3ℓ≥3，⟨ϕℓ⟩c=0\left\langle \phi^{\ell} \right\rangle_c = 0⟨ϕℓ⟩c​=0

因此，特征函数的累积量展开可以简化为：

exp⁡[∑ℓ=1∞(−ik)ℓℓ!⟨ϕℓ⟩c]=exp⁡[−ik⟨ϕ⟩c−k22⟨ϕ2⟩c]\exp \left[ \sum_{\ell=1}^{\infty} \frac{(-\mathrm{i} k)^{\ell}}{\ell!} \left\langle \phi^{\ell} \right\rangle_c \right] = \exp \left[ -\mathrm{i} k \left\langle \phi \right\rangle_c - \frac{k^2}{2} \left\langle \phi^2 \right\rangle_c \right]exp[ℓ=1∑∞​ℓ!(−ik)ℓ​⟨ϕℓ⟩c​]=exp[−ik⟨ϕ⟩c​−2k2​⟨ϕ2⟩c​]

代入累积量的值：

=exp⁡[−ikh−k22K]= \exp \left[ -\mathrm{i} k h - \frac{k^2}{2} K \right]=exp[−ikh−2k2​K]

这个等式表明，对于正态分布的随机变量，其特征函数可以通过均值和方差的累积量来表示。由于高阶累积量为零，特征函数的展开只包含到二阶项。这是正态分布的一个重要性质，反映了其完全由均值和方差决定。

Now consider the following Gaussian integral involving NNN variables,

JN=∫−∞∞∏i=1N dϕiexp⁡[−∑i,jKi,j2ϕiϕj+∑ihiϕi].\begin{equation*} \mathcal{J}_{N}=\int_{-\infty}^{\infty} \prod_{i=1}^{N} \mathrm{~d} \phi_{i} \exp \left[-\sum_{i, j} \frac{K_{i, j}}{2} \phi_{i} \phi_{j}+\sum_{i} h_{i} \phi_{i}\right] . \tag{3.43} \end{equation*}JN​=∫−∞∞​i=1∏N​ dϕi​exp[−i,j∑​2Ki,j​​ϕi​ϕj​+i∑​hi​ϕi​].​(3.43)​

It can be reduced to a product of NNN one-dimensional integrals by diagonalizing the matrix K≡Ki,j\mathbf{K} \equiv K_{i, j}K≡Ki,j​. Since we need only consider symmetric matrices ( Ki,j=K_{i, j}=Ki,j​= Kj,iK_{j, i}Kj,i​ ), the eigenvalues are real, and the eigenvectors can be made orthonormal. Let us denote the eigenvectors and eigenvalues of K\mathbf{K}K by q^\widehat{q}q​ and KqK_{q}Kq​, respectively, i.e. Kq^=Kqq^\mathbf{K} \widehat{q}=K_{q} \widehat{q}Kq​=Kq​q​. The vectors {q^}\{\widehat{q}\}{q​} form a new coordinate basis in the original NNN-dimensional space. Any point in this space can be represented either by coordinates {ϕi}\left\{\phi_{i}\right\}{ϕi​}, or {ϕ~q}\left\{\widetilde{\phi}_{q}\right\}{ϕ​q​} with ϕi=∑qϕ~qq^i\phi_{i}=\sum_{q} \widetilde{\phi}_{q} \widehat{q}_{i}ϕi​=∑q​ϕ​q​q​i​. We can now change the integration variables from {ϕi}\left\{\phi_{i}\right\}{ϕi​} to {ϕ~q}\left\{\widetilde{\phi}_{q}\right\}{ϕ​q​}. The Jacobian associated with this unitary transformation is unity, and

JN=∏q=1N∫−∞∞dϕ~qexp⁡[−Kq2ϕ~q2+h~qϕ~q]=∏q=1N2πKqexp⁡[h~qKq−1h~q2].\begin{equation*} \mathcal{J}_{N}=\prod_{q=1}^{N} \int_{-\infty}^{\infty} \mathrm{d} \widetilde{\phi}_{q} \exp \left[-\frac{K_{q}}{2} \widetilde{\phi}_{q}^{2}+\widetilde{h}_{q} \widetilde{\phi}_{q}\right]=\prod_{q=1}^{N} \sqrt{\frac{2 \pi}{K_{q}}} \exp \left[\frac{\widetilde{h}_{q} K_{q}^{-1} \widetilde{h}_{q}}{2}\right] . \tag{3.44} \end{equation*}JN​=q=1∏N​∫−∞∞​dϕ​q​exp[−2Kq​​ϕ​q2​+hq​ϕ​q​]=q=1∏N​Kq​2π​​exp[2hq​Kq−1​hq​​].​(3.44)​

The final expression can be represented in terms of the original coordinates by using the inverse matrix K−1\mathbf{K}^{-1}K−1, such that K−1K=1\mathbf{K}^{-1} \mathbf{K}=\mathbf{1}K−1K=1. Since the determinant of the matrix is independent of the choice of basis, det⁡K=∏qKq\operatorname{det} \mathbf{K}=\prod_{q} K_{q}detK=∏q​Kq​, and

JN=(2π)Ndet⁡Kexp⁡[∑i,jKi,j−12hihj].\begin{equation*} \mathcal{J}_{N}=\sqrt{\frac{(2 \pi)^{N}}{\operatorname{det} \mathbf{K}}} \exp \left[\sum_{i, j} \frac{K_{i, j}^{-1}}{2} h_{i} h_{j}\right] . \tag{3.45} \end{equation*}JN​=detK(2π)N​​exp[i,j∑​2Ki,j−1​​hi​hj​].​(3.45)​

Regarding {ϕi}\left\{\phi_{i}\right\}{ϕi​} as Gaussian random variable distributed with a joint probability distribution function proportional to the integrand of Eq. (3.43), the joint characteristic function is given by

⟨e−i∑jkjϕj⟩=exp⁡[−i∑i,jKi,j−1hikj−∑i,jKi,j−12kikj].\begin{equation*} \left\langle\mathrm{e}^{-\mathrm{i} \sum_{j} k_{j} \phi_{j}}\right\rangle=\exp \left[-\mathrm{i} \sum_{i, j} K_{i, j}^{-1} h_{i} k_{j}-\sum_{i, j} \frac{K_{i, j}^{-1}}{2} k_{i} k_{j}\right] . \tag{3.46} \end{equation*}⟨e−i∑j​kj​ϕj​⟩=exp[−ii,j∑​Ki,j−1​hi​kj​−i,j∑​2Ki,j−1​​ki​kj​].​(3.46)​

Moments of the distribution are obtained from derivatives of the characteristic function with respect to kik_{i}ki​, and cumulants from derivatives of its logarithm. Hence, Eq. (3.46) implies

{⟨ϕi⟩c=∑jKi,j−1hj⟨ϕiϕj⟩c=Ki,j−1.(3.47)\left\{\begin{array}{l} \left\langle\phi_{i}\right\rangle_{c}=\sum_{j} K_{i, j}^{-1} h_{j} \tag{3.47}\\ \left\langle\phi_{i} \phi_{j}\right\rangle_{c}=K_{i, j}^{-1} . \end{array}\right.{⟨ϕi​⟩c​=∑j​Ki,j−1​hj​⟨ϕi​ϕj​⟩c​=Ki,j−1​.​(3.47)

Another useful form of Eq. (3.46) is

⟨exp⁡(A)⟩=exp⁡[⟨A⟩c+12⟨A2⟩c],\begin{equation*} \langle\exp (A)\rangle=\exp \left[\langle A\rangle_{c}+\frac{1}{2}\left\langle A^{2}\right\rangle_{c}\right], \tag{3.48} \end{equation*}⟨exp(A)⟩=exp[⟨A⟩c​+21​⟨A2⟩c​],​(3.48)​

==where A=∑iaiϕiA=\sum_{i} a_{i} \phi_{i}A=∑i​ai​ϕi​ is any linear combination of Gaussian distributed variables==. We used this result earlier in computing the order parameter correlations in the presence of phase fluctuations in a superfluid.

Gaussian functional integrals are a limiting case of the above many variable integrals. Consider the points iii as the sites of a ddd-dimensional lattice and let the spacing go to zero. In the continuum limit, {ϕi}\left\{\phi_{i}\right\}{ϕi​} go over to a function ϕ(x)\phi(\mathbf{x})ϕ(x), and the matrix KijK_{i j}Kij​ is replaced by a kernel K(x,x′)K\left(\mathbf{x}, \mathbf{x}^{\prime}\right)K(x,x′). The natural generalization of Eq. (3.45) is

∫−∞∞Dϕ(x)exp⁡[−∫ddxddx′K(x,x′)2ϕ(x)ϕ(x′)+∫ddxh(x)ϕ(x)]∝(det⁡K)−1/2exp⁡[∫ ddxddx′K−1(x,x′)2h(x)h(x′)],\begin{gather*} \int_{-\infty}^{\infty} \mathcal{D} \phi(\mathbf{x}) \exp \left[-\int \mathrm{d}^{d} \mathbf{x d}^{d} \mathbf{x}^{\prime} \frac{K\left(\mathbf{x}, \mathbf{x}^{\prime}\right)}{2} \phi(\mathbf{x}) \phi\left(\mathbf{x}^{\prime}\right)+\int \mathrm{d}^{d} \mathbf{x} h(\mathbf{x}) \phi(\mathbf{x})\right] \\ \propto(\operatorname{det} \mathbf{K})^{-1 / 2} \exp \left[\int \mathrm{~d}^{d} \mathbf{x d}^{d} \mathbf{x}^{\prime} \frac{K^{-1}\left(\mathbf{x}, \mathbf{x}^{\prime}\right)}{2} h(\mathbf{x}) h\left(\mathbf{x}^{\prime}\right)\right], \tag{3.49} \end{gather*}∫−∞∞​Dϕ(x)exp[−∫ddxddx′2K(x,x′)​ϕ(x)ϕ(x′)+∫ddxh(x)ϕ(x)]∝(detK)−1/2exp[∫ ddxddx′2K−1(x,x′)​h(x)h(x′)],​(3.49)​

where the inverse kernel K−1(x,x′)K^{-1}\left(\mathbf{x}, \mathbf{x}^{\prime}\right)K−1(x,x′) satisfies

∫ddx′K(x,x′)K−1(x′,x′′)=δd(x−x′′)\begin{equation*} \int \mathrm{d}^{d} \mathbf{x}^{\prime} K\left(\mathbf{x}, \mathbf{x}^{\prime}\right) K^{-1}\left(\mathbf{x}^{\prime}, \mathbf{x}^{\prime \prime}\right)=\delta^{d}\left(\mathbf{x}-\mathbf{x}^{\prime \prime}\right) \tag{3.50} \end{equation*}∫ddx′K(x,x′)K−1(x′,x′′)=δd(x−x′′)​(3.50)​

The notation Dϕ(x)\mathcal{D} \phi(\mathbf{x})Dϕ(x) is used to denote the functional integral. There is a constant of proportionality, (2π)N/2(2 \pi)^{N / 2}(2π)N/2, left out of Eq. (3.49). Although formally infinite in the continuum limit of N→∞N \rightarrow \inftyN→∞, it does not affect the averages that are obtained as derivatives of such integrals. In particular, for Gaussian distributed functions, Eq. (3.47) generalizes to

{⟨ϕ(x)⟩c=∫ddx′K−1(x,x′)h(x′)⟨ϕ(x)ϕ(x′)⟩c=K−1(x,x′)(3.51)\begin{cases}\langle\phi(\mathbf{x})\rangle_{c} & =\int \mathrm{d}^{d} \mathbf{x}^{\prime} K^{-1}\left(\mathbf{x}, \mathbf{x}^{\prime}\right) h\left(\mathbf{x}^{\prime}\right) \tag{3.51}\\ \left\langle\phi(\mathbf{x}) \phi\left(\mathbf{x}^{\prime}\right)\right\rangle_{c} & =K^{-1}\left(\mathbf{x}, \mathbf{x}^{\prime}\right)\end{cases}{⟨ϕ(x)⟩c​⟨ϕ(x)ϕ(x′)⟩c​​=∫ddx′K−1(x,x′)h(x′)=K−1(x,x′)​(3.51)

In dealing with small fluctuations to the Landau-Ginzburg Hamiltonian, we encountered the quadratic form

∫ddx[(∇ϕ)2+ϕ2/ξ2]≡∫ddxddx′ϕ(x′)δd(x−x′)(−∇2+ξ−2)ϕ(x)\begin{equation*} \int \mathrm{d}^{d} \mathbf{x}\left[(\nabla \phi)^{2}+\phi^{2} / \xi^{2}\right] \equiv \int \mathrm{d}^{d} \mathbf{x d}^{d} \mathbf{x}^{\prime} \phi\left(\mathbf{x}^{\prime}\right) \delta^{d}\left(\mathbf{x}-\mathbf{x}^{\prime}\right)\left(-\nabla^{2}+\xi^{-2}\right) \phi(\mathbf{x}) \tag{3.52} \end{equation*}∫ddx[(∇ϕ)2+ϕ2/ξ2]≡∫ddxddx′ϕ(x′)δd(x−x′)(−∇2+ξ−2)ϕ(x)​(3.52)​

which implies the kernel

K(x,x′)=Kδd(x−x′)(−∇2+ξ−2)\begin{equation*} K\left(\mathbf{x}, \mathbf{x}^{\prime}\right)=K \delta^{d}\left(\mathbf{x}-\mathbf{x}^{\prime}\right)\left(-\nabla^{2}+\xi^{-2}\right) \tag{3.53} \end{equation*}K(x,x′)=Kδd(x−x′)(−∇2+ξ−2)​(3.53)​

Following Eq. (3.50), the inverse kernel satisfies

K∫ ddx′′δd(x−x′′)(−∇2+ξ−2)K−1(x′′−x′)=δd(x′−x)\begin{equation*} K \int \mathrm{~d}^{d} \mathbf{x}^{\prime \prime} \delta^{d}\left(\mathbf{x}-\mathbf{x}^{\prime \prime}\right)\left(-\nabla^{2}+\xi^{-2}\right) K^{-1}\left(\mathbf{x}^{\prime \prime}-\mathbf{x}^{\prime}\right)=\delta^{d}\left(\mathbf{x}^{\prime}-\mathbf{x}\right) \tag{3.54} \end{equation*}K∫ ddx′′δd(x−x′′)(−∇2+ξ−2)K−1(x′′−x′)=δd(x′−x)​(3.54)​

which implies the differential equation

K(−∇2+ξ−2)K−1(x)=δd(x)\begin{equation*} K\left(-\nabla^{2}+\xi^{-2}\right) K^{-1}(\mathbf{x})=\delta^{d}(\mathbf{x}) \tag{3.55} \end{equation*}K(−∇2+ξ−2)K−1(x)=δd(x)​(3.55)​

Comparing with Eq. (3.14) indicates K−1(x)=⟨ϕ(x)ϕ(0)⟩=−Id(x)/KK^{-1}(\mathbf{x})=\langle\phi(\mathbf{x}) \phi(\mathbf{0})\rangle=-I_{d}(\mathbf{x}) / KK−1(x)=⟨ϕ(x)ϕ(0)⟩=−Id​(x)/K, as obtained before by a less direct method.

3.6 Fluctuation corrections to the saddle point

We can now examine how fluctuations around the saddle point solution modify the free energy, and other macroscopic properties. Starting with Eq. (3.5), the partition function including small fluctuations is

Z≈exp⁡[−V(t2mˉ2+umˉ4)]∫Dϕℓ(x)exp⁡{−K2∫ ddx[(∇ϕℓ)2+ϕℓ2ξℓ2]}⋅∫Dϕt(x)exp⁡{−K2∫ ddx[(∇ϕt)2+ϕt2ξt2]}\begin{align*} & Z \approx \exp \left[-V\left(\frac{t}{2} \bar{m}^{2}+u \bar{m}^{4}\right)\right] \int \mathcal{D} \phi_{\ell}(\mathbf{x}) \exp \left\{-\frac{K}{2} \int \mathrm{~d}^{d} \mathbf{x}\left[\left(\nabla \phi_{\ell}\right)^{2}+\frac{\phi_{\ell}^{2}}{\xi_{\ell}^{2}}\right]\right\} \\ & \cdot \int \mathcal{D} \phi_{t}(\mathbf{x}) \exp \left\{-\frac{K}{2} \int \mathrm{~d}^{d} \mathbf{x}\left[\left(\nabla \phi_{t}\right)^{2}+\frac{\phi_{t}^{2}}{\xi_{t}^{2}}\right]\right\} \tag{3.56} \end{align*}​Z≈exp[−V(2t​mˉ2+umˉ4)]∫Dϕℓ​(x)exp{−2K​∫ ddx[(∇ϕℓ​)2+ξℓ2​ϕℓ2​​]}⋅∫Dϕt​(x)exp{−2K​∫ ddx[(∇ϕt​)2+ξt2​ϕt2​​]}​(3.56)​

Each of the Gaussian kernels is diagonalized by the Fourier transforms

ϕ~(q)=∫ddxexp⁡(−iq⋅x)ϕ(x)/V\widetilde{\phi}(\mathbf{q})=\int \mathrm{d}^{d} \mathbf{x} \exp (-\mathrm{iq} \cdot \mathbf{x}) \phi(\mathbf{x}) / \sqrt{V}ϕ​(q)=∫ddxexp(−iq⋅x)ϕ(x)/V​

and with corresponding eigenvalues K(q)=K(q2+ξ−2)K(\mathbf{q})=K\left(q^{2}+\xi^{-2}\right)K(q)=K(q2+ξ−2). The resulting determinant of K\mathbf{K}K is a product of such eigenvalues, and hence

ln⁡det⁡K=∑qln⁡K(q)=V∫ ddq(2π)dln⁡[K(q2+ξ−2)].\begin{equation*} \ln \operatorname{det} \mathbf{K}=\sum_{\mathbf{q}} \ln K(\mathbf{q})=V \int \frac{\mathrm{~d}^{d} \mathbf{q}}{(2 \pi)^{d}} \ln \left[K\left(q^{2}+\xi^{-2}\right)\right] . \tag{3.57} \end{equation*}lndetK=q∑​lnK(q)=V∫(2π)d ddq​ln[K(q2+ξ−2)].​(3.57)​

The free energy resulting from Eq. (3.56) is then given by

βf=−ln⁡ZV=tmˉ22+umˉ4+12∫ ddq(2π)dln⁡[K(q2+ξℓ−2)]+n−12∫ ddq(2π)dln⁡[K(q2+ξt−2)].\begin{align*} \beta f= & -\frac{\ln Z}{V}=\frac{t \bar{m}^{2}}{2}+u \bar{m}^{4}+\frac{1}{2} \int \frac{\mathrm{~d}^{d} \mathbf{q}}{(2 \pi)^{d}} \ln \left[K\left(q^{2}+\xi_{\ell}^{-2}\right)\right] \tag{3.58}\\ & +\frac{n-1}{2} \int \frac{\mathrm{~d}^{d} \mathbf{q}}{(2 \pi)^{d}} \ln \left[K\left(q^{2}+\xi_{t}^{-2}\right)\right] . \end{align*}βf=​−VlnZ​=2tmˉ2​+umˉ4+21​∫(2π)d ddq​ln[K(q2+ξℓ−2​)]+2n−1​∫(2π)d ddq​ln[K(q2+ξt−2​)].​(3.58)​

(Note that there are n−1n-1n−1 transverse components.) Using the dependence of the correlation lengths on reduced temperature, the singular part of the heat capacity is obtained as

Csingular ∝−∂2(βf)∂2t={0+n2∫ ddq(2π)d1(Kq2+t)2 for t>018u+2∫ ddq(2π)d1(Kq2−2t)2 for t<0.(3.59)C_{\text {singular }} \propto-\frac{\partial^{2}(\beta f)}{\partial^{2} t}= \begin{cases}0+\frac{n}{2} \int \frac{\mathrm{~d}^{d} \mathbf{q}}{(2 \pi)^{d}} \frac{1}{\left(K q^{2}+t\right)^{2}} & \text { for } t>0 \tag{3.59}\\ \frac{1}{8 u}+2 \int \frac{\mathrm{~d}^{d} \mathbf{q}}{(2 \pi)^{d}} \frac{1}{\left(K q^{2}-2 t\right)^{2}} & \text { for } t<0 .\end{cases}Csingular ​∝−∂2t∂2(βf)​=⎩⎨⎧​0+2n​∫(2π)d ddq​(Kq2+t)21​8u1​+2∫(2π)d ddq​(Kq2−2t)21​​ for t>0 for t<0.​(3.59)

注意，在 t→0t\rightarrow 0t→0 时，即临界点处，存在一个gap 。

The correction terms are proportional to

CF=1K2∫ ddq(2π)d1(q2+ξ−2)2.\begin{equation*} C_{F}=\frac{1}{K^{2}} \int \frac{\mathrm{~d}^{d} \mathbf{q}}{(2 \pi)^{d}} \frac{1}{\left(q^{2}+\xi^{-2}\right)^{2}} . \tag{3.60} \end{equation*}CF​=K21​∫(2π)d ddq​(q2+ξ−2)21​.​(3.60)​

The integral has dimensions of (length) 4−d{ }^{4-d}4−d, and changes behavior at d=4d=4d=4. For d>4d>4d>4 the integral diverges at large q\mathbf{q}q, and is dominated by the upper cutoff Λ≃1/a\Lambda \simeq 1 / aΛ≃1/a, where aaa is the lattice spacing. For d<4d<4d<4, the integral is convergent in both limits. It can be made dimensionless by rescaling q\mathbf{q}q by ξ−1\xi^{-1}ξ−1, and is hence proportional to ξ4−d\xi^{4-d}ξ4−d. Therefore

CF≃1K2{a4−d for d>4ξ4−d for d<4(3.61)C_{F} \simeq \frac{1}{K^{2}} \begin{cases}a^{4-d} & \text { for } d>4 \tag{3.61}\\ \xi^{4-d} & \text { for } d<4\end{cases}CF​≃K21​{a4−dξ4−d​ for d>4 for d<4​(3.61)

Fig. 3.3 The saddle point heat capacity (solid line), plus the corrections due to Gaussian fluctuations (dashed lines). The corrections simply modify the discontinuity in dimensions d>4d>4d>4 (left), but are divergent in d≤4d \leq 4d≤4 (right).

In dimensions d>4d>4d>4, fluctuation corrections to the heat capacity add a constant term to the background on each side of the transition. However, the primary form of the singularity, a discontinuity in CCC, is not changed. For d<4d<4d<4, the divergence of ξ∝t−1/2\xi \propto t^{-1 / 2}ξ∝t−1/2, at the transition leads to a correction term from Eq. (3.61) which is more important than the original discontinuity. Indeed, the correction term corresponds to an exponent α=(4−d)/2\alpha=(4-d) / 2α=(4−d)/2. However, this is only the first correction to the saddle point result. The divergence of CFC_{F}CF​ merely implies that the saddle point conclusions are no longer reliable in dimensions d≤4d \leq 4d≤4, below the so-called upper critical dimension. Although we obtained this dimension by looking at the fluctuation corrections to the heat capacity, we would have reached the same conclusion in examining the singular part of any other quantity, such as magnetization or susceptibility. The contributions due to fluctuations always modify the leading singular behavior, and hence the critical exponents, in dimensions $d \leq 4$.

3.7 The Ginzburg criterion

We have thus established the importance of fluctuations, and identified them as the probable reason for the failure of the saddle point approximation to correctly describe the observed exponents. However, as noted earlier, there are some materials, such as superconductors, in which the experimental results are well fitted to the singular forms predicted by this approximation. Can we quantify why fluctuations are less important in superconductors than in other phase transitions?

Equation (3.61) indicates that fluctuation corrections become important due to the divergence of the correlation length. Within the saddle point approximation, ==the correlation length diverges as ξ≈ξ0∣t∣−1/2\xi \approx \xi_{0}|t|^{-1 / 2}ξ≈ξ0​∣t∣−1/2, where t=(Tc−T)/Tct=\left(T_{c}-T\right) / T_{c}t=(Tc​−T)/Tc​ is the reduced temperature, and ξ0≈K\xi_{0} \approx \sqrt{K}ξ0​≈K​ is a microscopic length scale. In principle, ξ0\xi_{0}ξ0​ can be measured experimentally from fitting scattering line shapes.== It has to approximately equal the size of the units that undergo ordering at the phase transition. For the liquid-gas transition, ξ0\xi_{0}ξ0​ can be estimated as (vc)1/3\left(v_{c}\right)^{1 / 3}(vc​)1/3, where vcv_{c}vc​ is the critical atomic volume. In superfluids, ξ0\xi_{0}ξ0​ is approximately the thermal wavelength λ(T)\lambda(T)λ(T). Both these estimates are of the order of a few atomic spacings, 1−10A˚1-10 \AA1−10A˚. On the other hand, the underlying unit for superconductors is a Cooper pair. The paired electrons are forced apart by their Coulomb repulsion, resulting in a relatively large separation of ξ0≈103A˚\xi_{0} \approx 10^{3} \AAξ0​≈103A˚.

超流或气液相变，特征微观长度：1−10A˚1-10 \AA1−10A˚.

超导，特征微观长度 ξ0≈103A˚\xi_{0} \approx 10^{3} \AAξ0​≈103A˚.

The importance of fluctuations can be gauged by comparing the two terms in Eq. (3.59); the saddle point discontinuity ΔCSP∝1/u\Delta C_{\mathrm{SP}} \propto 1 / uΔCSP​∝1/u, and the correction term CFC_{F}CF​. Since K∝ξ02K \propto \xi_{0}^{2}K∝ξ02​, the correction term is proportional to ξ0−dt−(4−d)/2\xi_{0}^{-d} t^{-(4-d) / 2}ξ0−d​t−(4−d)/2 （见3.61）. Thus fluctuations are important provided,

ξ0−dt−4−d2≫ΔCSP⟹∣t∣≪tG≃1(ξ0dΔCSP)24−d\begin{equation*} \xi_{0}^{-d} t^{-\frac{4-d}{2}} \gg \Delta C_{S P} \quad \Longrightarrow \quad|t| \ll t_{G} \simeq \frac{1}{\left(\xi_{0}^{d} \Delta C_{S P}\right)^{\frac{2}{4-d}}} \tag{3.62} \end{equation*}ξ0−d​t−24−d​≫ΔCSP​⟹∣t∣≪tG​≃(ξ0d​ΔCSP​)4−d2​1​​(3.62)​

当鞍点近似的比热容在临界点处的不连续能够被涨落修正cover掉时，涨落修正变得重要，它会使得相变临界量发生漂移。

The above requirement is known as the Ginzburg criterion. Naturally in d<4d<4d<4, the inequality is satisfied sufficiently close to the critical point. However, the resolution of the experiment may not be good enough to get closer than the Ginzburg reduced temperature tGt_{G}tG​. If so, the apparent singularities at reduced temperatures t>tGt>t_{G}t>tG​ may show saddle point behavior. It is this apparent discontinuity that then appears in Eq. (3.62), and may be used to self-consistently estimate tGt_{G}tG​. Clearly, $\Delta C_{S P}$ and $\xi_{0}$ can both be measured in dimensionless units; ξ0\xi_{0}ξ0​ in units of atomic size aaa, and ΔCSP\Delta C_{S P}ΔCSP​ in units of NkBN k_{\mathrm{B}}NkB​. (玻尔兹曼常数 kB=1.380649×10−23 J/Kk_{\mathrm B} = 1.380649 \times 10^{-23} \, \text{J/K}kB​=1.380649×10−23J/K ) The latter is of the order of unity for most transitions, and thus tG≈ξ0−6t_{G} \approx \xi_{0}^{-6}tG​≈ξ0−6​ in d=3d=3d=3. In cases where ξ0\xi_{0}ξ0​ is a few atomic spacings, a resolution of tG≈10−1−10−2t_{G} \approx 10^{-1}-10^{-2}tG​≈10−1−10−2 will suffice. However, in superconductors with ξ0≈103a\xi_{0} \approx 10^{3} aξ0​≈103a, a resolution of tG<10−18t_{G}<10^{-18}tG​<10−18 is necessary to see any fluctuation effects. This is much beyond the ability of current apparatus. The newer ceramic（陶瓷） high-temperature superconductors have a much smaller coherence length of ξ0≈10a\xi_{0} \approx 10 aξ0​≈10a, and they indeed show some effects of fluctuations.

Again, it is worth emphasizing that a similar criterion could have been obtained by examining any other quantity. Fluctuations corrections become important in measurement of a quantity XXX for t≪tG(X)≃A(X)ξ0−2d/(4−d)t \ll t_{G}(X) \simeq A(X) \xi_{0}^{-2 d /(4-d)}t≪tG​(X)≃A(X)ξ0−2d/(4−d)​. However, the coefficient A(X)A(X)A(X) may be different (by one or two orders of magnitude) for different quantities. So, it is in principle possible to observe saddle point behavior in one quantity, while fluctuations are important in another quantity measured at the same resolution. Of course, fluctuations will always become important at sufficiently high resolutions.

A summary of the results obtained so far from the Landau-Ginzburg approach is as follows:

  • ==For dimensions ddd greater than an upper critical dimension of du=4d_{u}=4du​=4, the saddle point approximation is valid, and singular behavior at the critical point is described by exponents α=0,β=1/2,γ=1,ν=1/2\alpha=0, \beta=1 / 2, \gamma=1, \nu=1 / 2α=0,β=1/2,γ=1,ν=1/2, and η=0\eta=0η=0.==
  • ==For ddd less than a lower critical dimension ( dℓ=2d_{\ell}=2dℓ​=2 for continuous symmetry, and dℓ=1d_{\ell}=1dℓ​=1 for discrete symmetry) fluctuations are strong enough to destroy the ordered phase.==
  • ==In the intermediate dimensions, dℓ≤d≤dud_{\ell} \leq d \leq d_{u}dℓ​≤d≤du​, fluctuations are strong enough to change the saddle point results, but not sufficiently dominant to completely destroy order. Unfortunately, or happily, this is the case of interest to us in d=3d=3d=3.==
